H: Lightest element. Gas of diatomic molecules. Highly combustible.
Be: Steel-gray, strong, lightweight and brittle alkaline earth metal.
O: Colorless, odorless, tasteless gas essential to living organisms.
F: Highly reactive pale yellow diatomic gas. Most electronegative element.
Fe: Most common element on Earth. Belongs to first transition series and group 8 of periodic table.
Ni: Silvery-white lustrous metal with a slight golden tinge.
Cu: Soft, malleable, and ductile metal with high thermal and electrical conductivity.
Zn: First element in group 12 of the periodic table. Chemically similar to magnesium.
Pd: Rare and lustrous silvery-white metal with greatest density of any element.
Ce: Soft, ductile, and silvery-white metal that tarnishes when exposed to air. Belongs to the lanthanide series.
Pr: Soft and traditionally considered to be one of the rare-earth elements. Belongs to the lanthanide series.
Nd: Fourth member of the lanthanide series and traditionally considered to be one of the rare-earth elements.
Pm: Fifth member of the lanthanide series and traditionally considered to be one of the rare-earth elements. Radioactive.
Sm: Sixth member of the lanthanide series and traditionally considered to be one of the rare-earth elements.
Eu: Soft, silvery-white metal that tarnishes when exposed to air. Belongs to the lanthanide series.
Gd: Silvery-white, malleable, and ductile rare earth metal. Third most abundant rare earth element.
Li: Composed of three electrons bound to a nucleus containing three protons. Common alkali metal.
Na: Very soft silvery-white metal. Sixth most abundant element on Earth.
K: Silvery-white metal that is soft enough to be cut with a knife with little force. Reacts rapidly with atmospheric oxygen.
